results.abstract: Museum of Man in San Diego opens new exhibit on human evolution featuring more than 100 touchable models, of early humans, other primates and futuristic cyborgs; photo (M)

headline.main: Travel Advisory; Celebrating the Joy Of Opposable Thumbs

results.snippet: Visitors can touch more than 100 models of early humans, other primates and futuristic cyborgs -- part human, part machine -- in ''Footsteps Through Time,'' a new permanent exhibit of human evolution at the Museum of Man in San Diego.     The...
results.lead_paragraph: Visitors can touch more than 100 models of early humans, other primates and futuristic cyborgs -- part human, part machine -- in ''Footsteps Through Time,'' a new permanent exhibit of human evolution at the Museum of Man in San Diego. The 7,000-square-foot exhibit covers four million years of evolution with more than 75 display stations.

results.abstract: Hubble Space Telescope is back in operation after Columbia space shuttle astronauts replace malfunctioning power control unit in risky procedure likened to heart transplant; procedure required turning off all of telescope's power for first time; diagrm (M)

headline.main: Hubble Power Controller Replaced With Soft Touch

results.snippet: The Hubble Space Telescope is alive and in stable condition, with electricity surging through its instruments, after astronauts performed a heart-stopping replacement of its central power controller today.    With Hubble secured to a workbench across...
results.lead_paragraph: The Hubble Space Telescope is alive and in stable condition, with electricity surging through its instruments, after astronauts performed a heart-stopping replacement of its central power controller today. With Hubble secured to a workbench across the cargo bay of the space shuttle Columbia, two astronauts replaced the malfunctioning power control unit in a risky procedure that had been likened to a heart transplant.

results.lead_paragraph: DIGITAL BIOLOGY How Nature Is Transforming Our Technology and Our Lives. By Peter J. Bentley. Illustrated. 272 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $25.

results.abstract: White House withdraws nomination of Maj Gen Charles F Bolden to be deputy administration of NASA; cites Defense Department directive to limit service of senior military officers to civilian jobs during current war on terrorism (S)

headline.main: White House Withdraws Nominee for NASA

results.snippet: The White House today abruptly withdrew the nomination of a Marine general to be deputy administrator of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration.    NASA officials said the agency administrator, Sean O'Keefe, was advised of the decision to...
results.lead_paragraph: The White House today abruptly withdrew the nomination of a Marine general to be deputy administrator of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration. NASA officials said the agency administrator, Sean O'Keefe, was advised of the decision to withdraw the nomination of Maj. Gen. Charles F. Bolden late Tuesday, on the eve of his confirmation hearing before the Senate Committee on Commerce, Science and Transportation.

results.abstract: Six people are living in sawed-off corn silo in Hanksville, Utah, in project simulating life on Mars; project is latest wrinkle in private plan to persuade federal government to send humans to Mars sooner and for less money than envisioned by NASA; Dr Bjoern Grieger, mission commander and astrophysicist at Max Planck Institute for Aeronautics in Germany, comments; photos (L)

headline.main: Life Inside Tall Tin Can in Utah Is All Mars

results.snippet: In the red-rock desert west of this lonely little town, six seriously smart people are living in something that looks like a sawed-off corn silo and smells of their unwashed socks.    They have come to a fine spot for unorthodox behavior. A Mormon...
results.lead_paragraph: In the red-rock desert west of this lonely little town, six seriously smart people are living in something that looks like a sawed-off corn silo and smells of their unwashed socks. They have come to a fine spot for unorthodox behavior. A Mormon named Ebenezer Hanks came here in the 1880's to practice polygamy and nobody bothered him. The six recent pilgrims are practicing something even stranger and more isolating -- living on Mars.

results.abstract: Profile of Headlong Dance Theater of Philadelphia, which will perform Subirdia, its latest work, as part of Dance Theater Workshop's Around Town spring season at Duke on 42nd Street; photo (M)

headline.main: Cerebral Experiments That Can Take Flight

results.snippet: DOES experimental dance have to be intimidating? Not according to Headlong Dance Theater of Philadelphia, which likes to lace its cerebral offerings with sly humor. In ''Subirdia,'' the troupe's latest piece, the culture of birds is mirrored in...
results.lead_paragraph: DOES experimental dance have to be intimidating? Not according to Headlong Dance Theater of Philadelphia, which likes to lace its cerebral offerings with sly humor. In ''Subirdia,'' the troupe's latest piece, the culture of birds is mirrored in 1960's suburban America, complete with miniature houses and white picket fences. The dance portrays the antics of a single woman and two couples, with the men fighting over yards and swapping wives.

results.abstract: Airlines, hotel companies and others involved in travel have introduced advertising campaigns in recent weeks to encourage more travel; many new campaigns are directed at business travelers; specific campaigns noted (M)

headline.main: Airlines and hotel chains are spending plenty to revive travel, especially business travel.

results.snippet: BUSINESS travel has shown definite signs of life since the double shock of Sept. 11 and a slumping economy, but it is still limping. So airlines, hotel companies and others involved in travel have introduced campaigns in recent weeks to try to get...
results.lead_paragraph: BUSINESS travel has shown definite signs of life since the double shock of Sept. 11 and a slumping economy, but it is still limping. So airlines, hotel companies and others involved in travel have introduced campaigns in recent weeks to try to get things going at a brisk pace again. The problem is clear. Domestic airlines will lose $3.5 billion this year, Samuel C. Buttrick, an analyst with UBS Warburg, forecast recently. And while that is far less than the more than $6 billion loss in 2001, it is still the second-largest loss in industry history.

results.abstract: Team of Russian journalists win right to continue broadcasting on national television after being shut off airwaves in January in bankruptcy proceedings they say were rigged; government commission votes unanimously to award five-year broadcasting license to Media-Sotsium, nonprofit group that includes former Russian Prime Min Yevgeny M Primakov, business magnate Arkady Volsky and some of country's most critical journalists; supporters are doubtful about how much control journalists wil have over how station will be run (M)

headline.main: Nonstate TV In Russia Wins License To Broadcast

results.snippet: A team of Russian journalists, shut off the airwaves in January in bankruptcy proceedings they say were rigged, scored a victory today when they won the right to continue broadcasting on national television.    A government commission voted...
results.lead_paragraph: A team of Russian journalists, shut off the airwaves in January in bankruptcy proceedings they say were rigged, scored a victory today when they won the right to continue broadcasting on national television. A government commission voted unanimously to award a five-year broadcasting license to Media-Sotsium, a nonprofit organization that includes a former Russian prime minister, business magnates and some of this country's most critical journalists. The group will resume programming in May.

results.snippet: AT 57, Linda Ellerbee has survived cancer and the network news business to become a successful independent television producer. In other words, she's pretty tough.
results.lead_paragraph: AT 57, Linda Ellerbee has survived cancer and the network news business to become a successful independent television producer. In other words, she's pretty tough.
